revision.text:
{{Campaignbox Germanic Wars}} The '''Germanic Wars''' is a name given to a series of wars between the [[Ancient Rome|Romans]] and various [[Germanic peoples|Germanic tribes]] between 113 BC and 596 AD. The nature of these wars varied through time between Roman conquest, Germanic uprisings and later Germanic invasions in the [[Roman Empire]] that started in the late 2nd century BC. The series of conflicts, which began in the 5th century under the Western Roman Emperor [[Honorius (emperor)|Honorius]], led (along with internal strife) to the ultimate [[Decline of the Roman Empire|downfall]] of the [[Western Roman Empire]].
*[[Siege of Olbia]], c. 220 BC *[[Cimbrian War]], 113–101 BC **[[Battle of Noreia]] 112 BC<ref name="Theodor Mommsen: History of Rome">{{cite web|url=http://italian.classic-literature.co.uk/history-of-rome/04-the-revolution/ebook-page-67.asp|title=History of Rome: Book IV - The Revolution|last=Mommsen|first=Theodor|page=67|accessdate=2009-04-18}}</ref> **[[Battle of Agen (107 BC)|Battle of Agen]] 107 BC<ref name="Mommsen">[[Theodor Mommsen]], ''Römische Geschichte''. Vol. 2. ''Von der Schlacht von Pydna bis auf Sullas Tod.''. 3.Ed. Weidmann, Berlin 1861, S. 178. {{de icon}} (Roman History: From the battle of Pydna down to Sulla's death.) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=PX0PAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA178 Römische Geschichte: Bd. Von der Schlacht von Pydna bis auf Sullas Tod]''</ref> **[[Battle of Arausio]] 105 BC **[[Battle of Aquae Sextiae]] 102 BC **[[Battle of Vercellae]] 101 BC<ref name="Mosssman">{{cite book |title= History of Rome|last=Mossman |first= Theodor|year= 1908|publisher=Charles Scribner's SOns |location= New York |page=71 |url=http://italian.classic-literature.co.uk/history-of-rome/04-the-revolution/ebook-page-71.asp |accessdate=9 October 2009}}</ref> *[[Battle of Vosges (58 BC)|Battle of Vosges]] 58 BC *[[Battle of the Sabis]] 57 BC *''[[clades Lolliana]]'' 16 BC *[[Battle of the Lupia River]] 11 BC *[[Battle of the Teutoburg Forest]] 9 AD *[[Battle at the Pontes longi]] 15 *[[Battle of the Weser River]] 16 *[[Battle of the Angivarian Wall]] 16 *[[Battle of Baduhenna Wood]] 28 *[[Revolt of the Batavi]] 69-70 *[[Domitian#Campaign against the Chatti|Domitian's Campaign against the Chatti]] 82 *[[Marcomannic Wars]] 166–180 *[[Crisis of the Third Century]] **[[Battle at the Harzhorn]] c. 235 **[[Battle of Nicopolis ad Istrum]] 250 **[[Battle of Philippopolis (250)|Battle of Philippopolis]] 250 **[[Battle of Abrittus]] 251 **[[Battle of Mediolanum]] 259 **[[Battle of Augusta Vindelicorum]] 260 **[[Battle of Thermopylae (267)|Battle of Thermopylae]] 267 **[[Siege of Mainz (268)|Siege of Mainz]] 268 **[[Battle of Lake Benacus]] 268 **[[Siege of Augustodunum Haeduorum (269)|Siege of Augustodunum Haeduorum]] 269 **[[Battle of Naissus]] 269 **[[Battle of Placentia (271)|Battle of Placentia]] 271 **[[Battle of Fano]] 271 **[[Battle of Pavia (271)|Battle of Pavia]] 271 **[[Battle of Châlons (274)|Battle of Châlons]] 274 *[[Battle of Lingones]] 298 *[[Battle of Vindonissa]] 298 *[[Siege of Senonae]] 356 *[[Siege of Autun]] 356 *[[Battle of Reims (356)|Battle of Durocortorum]] 356 *[[Battle of Brumath]] 356 *[[Battle of Strasbourg|Battle of Argentoratum]] 357 *[[Battle of Solicinium]] 367 *[[Great Conspiracy]] 367–368 *[[Gothic War (376–382)]] **[[Battle of the Willows]] 377 **[[Battle of Adrianople]] 378 **[[Battle of Thessalonica (380)|Battle of Thessalonica]] 380 *[[Battle of Argentovaria]] 378 *[[Massacre of Thessalonica]] 390 *[[Battle of the Frigidus]] 394 *[[Gothic War (402-403)]] **[[Battle of Pollentia]] 402 **[[Battle of Verona (402)|Battle of Verona]] 403 *[[Battle of Faesulae (406)|Battle of Faesulae]] 406 *[[Battle of Mainz (406)|Battle of Moguntiacum]] 406 *[[Crossing of the Rhine]] 406 *[[Sack of Rome (410)|Sack of Rome]] 410 *[[Siege of Hippo Regius]] 430 *[[Battle of Narbonne (436)|Battle of Narbonne]] 436 *[[Battle of the Catalaunian Plains]] 451 *[[Sack of Aquileia]] 452 *[[Sack of Rome (455)|Sack of Rome]] 455 *[[Battle of Aylesford]] 455 *[[Battle of Órbigo (456)|Battle of Órbigo]] 456 *[[Battle of Arelate]] 458 *[[Battle of Cartagena (461)|Battle of Cartagena]] 461 *[[Battle of Orleans (463)|Battle of Orleans]] 463 *[[Battle of Bassianae]] 468 *[[Battle of Cap Bon (468)|Battle of Cap Bon]] 468 *[[Battle of Bolia]] 469 *[[Battle of Déols]] c. 469 *[[Battle of Ravenna (476)|Battle of Ravenna]] 476 *[[Battle of Soissons (486)|Battle of Soissons]] 486 *[[Battle of Isonzo (489)|Battle of Isonzo]] 489 *[[Battle of Verona (489)|Battle of Verona]] 489 *[[Vandalic War]] 533-534 **[[Battle of Ad Decimum]] 533 **[[Battle of Tricamarum]] 533 *[[Gothic War (535–554)]] **[[Siege of Rome (537–538)|Siege of Rome]] 537-538 **[[Battle of Faventia]] 542 **[[Battle of Mucellium]] 542 **[[Siege of Naples (543)|Siege of Naples]] 543 **[[Sack of Rome (546)|Sack of Rome]] 546 **[[Siege of Rome (549–550)|Siege of Rome]] 549-550 **[[Battle of Sena Gallica (551)|Battle of Sena Gallica]] 551 **[[Battle of Taginae]] 552 **[[Battle of Mons Lactarius]] 553 **[[Battle of the Volturnus (554)|Battle of the Volturnus]] 554 *[[Siege of Pavia (569–572)|Siege of Ticinum]] 569–572
==Chronology==
===3rd century BC=== *c. 220 BC, [[Siege of Olbia]] by Germanic [[Bastarnae|Basternae]] and [[Scirii]].
===2nd century BC=== {{Campaign| name=[[Cimbrian War]] |raw_name=Campaignbox Cimbrian War |battles=[[Battle of Noreia|Noreia]] – [[Battle of Arausio|Arausio]] – [[Battle of Aquae Sextiae|Aquae Sextiae]] – [[Battle of Vercellae|Vercellae]] }} [[File:The defeat of the Cimbri.jpg|thumb|300px|''The Defeat of the Cimbri'' by [[Alexandre-Gabriel Decamps|Alexandre Gabriel Décamps]]]] *113–101 BC, Germanic [[Germanic peoples#Collision with Rome|Collision with the Roman Republic]], [[Cimbrian War]], Begin of Germanic Wars. **112 BC, [[Battle of Noreia]],<ref name="Theodor Mommsen: History of Rome" /> Suicide of Consul [[Gnaeus Papirius Carbo (consul 113 BC)|Gnaeus Papirius Carbo]]. **107 BC, [[Helvetii]] defeat the Romans in the [[Battle of Agen (107 BC)|Battle of Agen]],<ref name="Mommsen"/> Consul [[Lucius Cassius Longinus (consul 107 BC)|Lucius Cassius Longinus]] dies in battle,<ref name="Mommsen"/> General [[Lucius Calpurnius Piso Caesoninus (consul 112 BC)|Lucius Calpurnius Piso Caesoninus]] dies in battle.<ref name="Mommsen"/> (Battle against Allies of the [[Cimbri]]) **105 BC, [[Battle of Arausio]], Execution of Roman General [[Marcus Aurelius Scaurus]], Proconsul [[Quintus Servilius Caepio]] and Consul [[Gnaeus Mallius Maximus]] exiled. **102 BC, Consul [[Gaius Marius]] defeats the [[Scirii]] and [[Teutons]] in the [[Battle of Aquae Sextiae]], Capture of King [[Teutobod]], Extermination of the [[Teutons]], [[Cimbri]] defeat Consul [[Quintus Lutatius Catulus]] in the [[Adige]] Valley.<ref>[[Florus]], ''[[wikisource:Epitome of Roman History|Epitome]]'' [[wikisource:Epitome of Roman History/Book 1#38|1.38.16-17]] and [[Valerius Maximus]], ''[http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/valmax.html Factorum et Dictorum Memorabilium]'' [http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/valmax6.html 6.1.ext.3] (in Latin)</ref> **101 BC, Roman consuls [[Gaius Marius]] and [[Manius Aquillius (consul 101 BC)|Manius Aquillius]] defeat the Cimbri in the [[Battle of Vercellae]],<ref name="Mosssman"/> King [[Boiorix]] dies in battle,<ref name="Mosssman"/> Extermination of the [[Cimbri]].<ref name="Mosssman"/>
===1st century BC=== [[File:Siege-alesia-vercingetorix-jules-cesar.jpg|thumb|300px|''Vercingetorix Throws Down His Arms at the Feet of Julius Caesar'' by [[Lionel Royer|Lionel Noel Royer]], 1899]] *58–51 BC, Conquest of [[Gaul|Celtic Gaul]] to the [[Rhine]] by [[Julius Caesar]], [[Gallic Wars]].<ref>''Caesar''. In: {{Interlanguage link multi|Hans Herzfeld|de|vertical-align=sup}} (1960): ''Geschichte in Gestalten'' (''History in figures''), vol. 1: ''A-E''. {{Interlanguage link multi|Das Fischer Lexikon|de|vertical-align=sup}} 37, Frankfurt 1963, p. 214. "Hauptquellen [betreffend Caesar]: Caesars eigene, wenn auch leicht tendenziöse Darstellungen des Gallischen und des Bürgerkrieges, die Musterbeispiele sachgemäßer Berichterstattung und stilistischer Klarheit sind" ("''Main sources [regarding Caesar]: Caesar's own, even though slightly tendentious depictions of the Gallic and the Civil Wars, which are paradigms of pertinent information and stylistic clarity''")</ref> **58 BC, [[Julius Caesar|Caesar]] decisively defeats the [[Helvetii]] in the [[Battle of the Arar]] and the [[Battle of Bibracte]], Caesar decisively defeats the [[Suebi|Suevi]], led by [[Ariovistus]], in the [[Battle of Vosges (58 BC)|Battle of Vosges]].<ref>[[Julius Caesar]], ''[[Commentarii de Bello Gallico]]'' [[Wikisource:The Gallic War (Caesar)/Book 1#31|1.31-53]]</ref><ref>[[Dio Cassius]], ''Roman History'' [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Cassius_Dio/38*.html#34 38.34-50]; see also [[Plutarch]], ''Life of Caesar'' [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Plutarch/Lives/Caesar*.html#19 19]</ref> **57 BC, [[Battle of the Sabis]]. **55 BC, Caesar's intervention against [[Tencteri and Usipetes|Usipetes and Tencteri]], Caesar defeats a [[Germanic peoples|Germanic]] army then massacres the women and children, totalling 430,000 people, somewhere near the [[Meuse]] and [[Rhine]] rivers, Caesar's first crossing of the Rhine against the [[Suebi|Suevi]], [[Caesar's invasions of Britain]]. **54 BCE, Destruction of the legion [[Legio XIV Gemina]] by the [[Eburones]] led by [[Cativolcus]] and [[Ambiorix]],<ref name="DGRBM">{{cite encyclopedia | last = Smith | first = William | authorlink = William Smith (lexicographer) | title = Ambiorix | editor = William Smith | encyclopedia = [[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Biography and Mythology]] | volume = 1 | pages = 138–139 | publisher = [[Little, Brown and Company]] | location = Boston | year = 1867 | url = http://www.ancientlibrary.com/smith-bio/0147.html | editor-link = William Smith (lexicographer)}}</ref><ref>Florus, III. 10. § 8.</ref> [[Lucius Aurunculeius Cotta]] dies in battle, [[Quintus Titurius Sabinus]] dies in battle. **53 BC, [[Julius Caesar|Caesar's]] retaliation against the [[Eburones]] second crossing of the Rhine, Extermination of the Eburones. **52 BC, [[Siege of Alesia|Fall of Celtic Gaul]], [[Gaul]] becomes a [[Roman province]]. *46 BC, Execution of [[Vercingetorix]] the Celt.<ref>Birkhan, Helmut, 1997, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=xFOTAAAAIAAJ&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s Die Kelten]'', p. 238. {{de icon}} (The Celts)</ref> *20 BC, [[Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa]], Governor of [[Transalpine Gaul]], Construction of military roads and especially the military road [[Colonia Copia Claudia Augusta Lugdunum|Lugdunum]]--[[Metz|Divodurum]]--[[Trier|Treverorum]]--[[Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium|Agrippinensium]] (from Lyon to Cologne). *16 BC, ''[[clades Lolliana]]'',<ref name="Suetonius-Augustus23">[[Suetonius]], ''Augustus'', [[wikisource:The Lives of the Twelve Caesars/Augustus#23|23]], ''Tiberius'', [[wikisource:The Lives of the Twelve Caesars/Tiberius#12|12]]; [[Tacitus]], ''Annals'', [[wikisource:The Annals (Tacitus)/Book 1#10|I.10]], [[wikisource:The Annals (Tacitus)/Book 3#48|III.48]]; [[Velleius Paterculus|Velleius]] II.97, 102; [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]], ''Nat. Hist.'' IX.35 (58); Dio, liv.6.</ref> Destruction of the legion [[Legio V Alaudae]] by [[Sicambri]] and their allies, Fall of the [[Noricum|Kingdom of Noricum]]. *16–13 BC, Emperor Augustus on the [[Rhine]], Reorganization of the Three Gauls (capital [[Trier]]), Decision to fortify the left bank of the Rhine and conquest of [[Germania]] to the [[Elbe]], Rome pays tribute to the [[Frisii]], Begin of invasions east of the Rhine by Rome, Construction of the modern city of [[Mainz]] begins. *12–9 BC, Invasions of [[Nero Claudius Drusus|Drusus I]] up the [[Elbe]] from the [[North Sea]], the [[Lippe]] and [[Main (river)|Main]], [[Battle of the Lupia River]], [[Cherusci]] and [[Sicambri]]<ref>Dio, ''[[wikisource:Dio's Roman History|Roman History]]'', [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Cassius_Dio/54*.html#33 LIV.33].</ref> subdued, [[Chatti]], [[Tencteri and Usipetes]] are overrun, Establishment of new forts by Rome, [[Arminius]] and Flavus sent to Rome. *9 BC, Creation of [[Germania|Magna Germania]] (capital [[Cologne]]), Pacification campaigns against the [[Germanic peoples|Germanic tribes]] by the Roman Empire, Deportation of 40,000 [[Sicambri]] west of the Rhine. *6–2 BC, [[Lucius Domitius Ahenobarbus (consul 16 BC)|Lucius Domitius Ahenobarbus']] invasions to the [[Elbe]].
===1st century=== *1–4 AD, Rise of the [[Chatti]]<ref>Several examples by Max Ihm, s. v. ''Cheruski'', in: ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=NAsgQQAACAAJ&dq=Paulys+Realencyclop%C3%A4die+der+classischen+Altertumswissenschaft+1899 Paulys Realencyclopädie der classischen Altertumswissenschaft]'' (RE) III.2, Stuttgart 1899, cols. 2270–2272. {{de icon}})</ref><ref name="Britannica Chatti">{{cite web | url = http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/107997/Chatti#218403.hook | date = September 2010 | title = Chatti in Encyclopædia Britannica | publisher = Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> and [[Bructeri]] (''immensum bellum'')<ref>[[Velleius]], ''[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Velleius_Paterculus/home.html Compendium of Roman History]'', [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Velleius_Paterculus/2D*.html book 2], 104,2.</ref> suppressed by [[Tiberius]], who reached the Elbe. *6–9, [[Great Illyrian Revolt|Uprising in Illyricum]], which cancels the major Roman project of war against Suevic [[Marcomanni]]. *6, [[Publius Quinctilius Varus|Varus]] succeeds Saturninus as governor of [[Germania]] with the mission of peacekeeping and the implementation of tax and judicial administration. [[Image:Otto Albert Koch Varusschlacht 1909.jpg|300px|thumb|''The Varus battle'' by [[Otto Albert Koch]], 1909]] *9, ''[[clades Variana]]'', Destruction of the legions [[Legio XVII|XVII]], [[Legio XVIII|XVIII]] and [[Legio XIX|XIX]] by [[Arminius]] in the [[Battle of the Teutoburg Forest|Battle of Teutoburg Forest]], Suicide of Administrator [[Publius Quinctilius Varus|Varus]], Loss of military camps east of the Rhine.,<ref>Wells, Peter S. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=w2x6i3N9DxMC&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s The Battle that stopped Rome]''. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. 2003, p. 187 ISBN 0-393-32643-8</ref><ref name="Bordewich">{{cite web | url = http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history-archaeology/ambush.html | date = September 2005 | title = ''The Ambush That Changed History'' | publisher = Fergus M. Bordewich, [[Smithsonian Magazine]] | accessdate = 2008-10-17}}</ref><ref name="Edward Shepherd Creasy - Germans under Arminius Revolt Against Rome">{{cite web | url = http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Great_Events_by_Famous_Historians,_Vol._2/Germans_under_Arminius_Revolt_Against_Rome | year = 1905 | title = ''Germans under Arminius Revolt Against Rome'' | publisher = Edward Shepherd Creasy, [[wikisource:The Great Events by Famous Historians/Volume 2|The Great Events by Famous Historians, Vol. 2]]}}</ref> Roman Empire is forced to strategically withdraw from [[Germania]]. *10–13, Military command of Tiberius in Germania and interventions in the valley of the Lippe, replaced by [[Germanicus]], Construction of ''[[Limes Germanicus]]'' begins. *14, Mutiny of the legions of Germania. *14–16, Roman retaliation against [[Cherusci]], [[Chatti]], [[Bructeri]] and [[Marsi (Germanic)|Marsi]], Capture of Arminius' wife. ** [[Battle of the Weser River]]. *17, Cessation of military offensives east of the [[Rhine]] by [[Tiberius]], Civil war between [[Germanic peoples|Germanic tribes]].<ref>Kevin Sweeney, ''[http://www.nujournal.com/page/content.detail/id/509454.html Scholars look at factors surrounding Hermann’s victory]''. www.nujournal.com 2010-10.</ref> *19, Death of [[Germanicus]]. *21, Assassination of [[Arminius]]. *28, Revolt of the [[Frisii]], Tax collectors hanged, Romans defeated in the [[Battle of Baduhenna Wood]]. *41, Raid against the [[Chauci]] under Emperor [[Claudius]], Recovery of third legionary standard lost in the [[Battle of the Teutoburg Forest]]. *50, Raid against the [[Chatti]] under Emperor [[Claudius]], Liberation of Roman prisoners.<ref>[[Tacitus]], ''Annals'', [[wikisource:The Annals (Tacitus)/Book 12#27|XII.27]]</ref> *69–70, [[Revolt of the Batavi]], Destruction of 2 Roman legions by the [[Batavi (Germanic tribe)|Batavi]]. *82–83, [[Domitian#Campaign against the Chatti|Raids]] against the [[Chatti]] under Emperor [[Domitian]]. *89, [[Lucius Antonius Saturninus]], [[Legio XIV Gemina]] and [[Legio XXI Rapax]] revolt against [[Rome]] with aid of the [[Chatti]].<ref name=jones-144>Dean-Jones, Lesley (1992), p. 144</ref>
===2nd century=== *c. 165, Invasion of [[Pannonia]] by [[Lombards]] and [[Ubii]]. *166–180, [[Germanic peoples|Germanic tribes]] invade the frontiers of the [[Roman Empire]], specifically the provinces of [[Raetia]] and [[Moesia]], [[Marcomannic Wars]]. *180, [[Goths]] reach the banks of the [[Black Sea]].
===3rd century=== {{Campaignbox Rome against the Alamanni}} {{Campaignbox Roman Empire against the Goths}}
*235–284, [[Crisis of the Third Century]]. **235, [[Battle at the Harzhorn]]. **238, Gothic raid on [[Histria (Sinoe)|Istria]],<ref name="Kulikowski, Michael 2007, p. 18">Kulikowski, Michael, 2007, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=QXM9SH4EALgC&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s Rome's Gothic Wars]'', p. 18.</ref> **248–249, Raid in [[Marcianopolis]] by Goths.<ref name="Kulikowski, Michael 2007, p. 18"/> **250, [[Battle of Philippopolis (250)|Siege of Philippopolis]] by Goths led by [[Cniva]].<ref>[[Jordanes]], ''[http://www.earth-history.com/Europe/Goths/jordanes-goths-04-3rdcentury.htm The Goths in the Third Century AD]'' in [https://books.google.com/books?id=rXh8g34W-qwC&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s THE ORIGIN AND DEEDS OF THE GOTHS], translated by Charles C. Mierow, www.earth-history.com</ref> **251, [[Battle of Abritus]], Emperor [[Decius]] dies in battle, Co-Emperor [[Herennius Etruscus]] dies in battle. **259, 300,000 [[Alemanni]] die in the [[Battle of Mediolanum]] (Milan). [[File:Limes Germanicus 2nd c.png|300px|thumb|right|300px|The area ([[Agri Decumates]]) between [[Main (river)|Main]] and [[Rhine]] was evacuated in 259 AD, dozens of [[Castra|Roman camps]] were abandoned.]] **259–260, Evacuation of the agrarian area [[Agri Decumates]] by the Roman Empire, Roman Empire retreats behind the Rhine. **260–274, Germanic usurper [[Postumus]] declares himself Emperor of the [[Gallic Empire]] including [[Roman Gaul]], [[Roman Britain]], [[Hispania|Roman Spain]] and Germania. **c. 267–269, [[Battle of Naissus#Background|Invasion of the Goths]], [[Battle of Thermopylae (267)|Battle of Thermopylae]], Gothic attacks on [[Marcianopolis]] and [[Uskudar|Chrysopolis]], Sack of [[Byzantium]]. **268, [[Siege of Mainz (268)|Siege of Mainz]], [[Battle of Lake Benacus]], assassination of Gallic Emperor [[Postumus]]. **269, [[Siege of Augustodunum Haeduorum (269)|Siege of Augustodunum Haeduorum]], [[Battle of Naissus]],<ref name=Zosimus>Zosimus, ''Historia Nova'', [http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/zosimus01_book1.htm book 1.43]</ref> end of Gothic Invasion, assassination of Gallic Emperor [[Marcus Aurelius Marius]]. **271, [[Battle of Placentia (271)|Battle of Placentia]], [[Battle of Fano]], [[Battle of Pavia (271)|Battle of Pavia]], Destruction of [[Alemanni]]c army, Assassination of [[Gaul|Gallic]] Emperor [[Victorinus]], Emperor [[Aurelian]] repelled another [[Goths|Gothic]] invasion but abandoned the province of [[Dacia]] north of [[Danube]] forever,<ref>Potter, David S., ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=g4ZmqsyC5kEC&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s A Companion to the Roman Empire]'', p. 270</ref> Construction of the [[Aurelian Walls|Aurelian Wall]] begins. **274, [[Battle of Châlons (274)|Battle of Châlons]], Surrender of the [[Gallic Empire]]. *298, [[Battle of Lingones]]. *298, [[Battle of Vindonissa]].
===4th century=== {{Campaignbox Barbarian Invasions}}
*332, Roman invasion north of the Danube under Emperor [[Constantine II (emperor)|Constantine II]], Capture of Gothic Prince [[Ariaricus]].<ref>[[Sozomen]], ''[[wikisource:Ecclesiastical history (Sozomen)|Ecclesiastical History]]'', [[wikisource:Ecclesiastical history (Sozomen)/Book I#Chapter 8|book 1, chapter 8]] & book 2, chapter 34.</ref><ref>Kulikowski, Michael, 2007, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=QXM9SH4EALgC&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s Rome's Gothic Wars]'', pp. 83-84.</ref><ref>Origo Constantini 6.32 mention the actions.</ref><ref>[[Eusebius of Caesarea|Eusebius]], ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=ueuDVbvRNy4C&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s The Life of the Blessed Emperor Constantine]'', IV.6</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">Odahl, Charles M., ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Ulpy0MMF29kC&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s Constantine and the Christian Empire]'', chapter X.</ref> *c. 350, Infiltration of [[Germania Inferior]] by [[Franks]]. *353–354, Raids against [[Alamanni]] under Emperor [[Constantius II]]. *356, Recapture of [[Colonia Claudia Ara Agrippinensium|Colonia Agrippina]] (Cologne) by Julian the Apostate, [[Siege of Senonae]] by Alamanni, [[Siege of Autun]] by [[Alemanni]], [[Battle of Durocortorum|Battle of Reims]], [[Battle of Brumath]]. *357, Invasion of Alemannic territory by Roman General [[Barbatio]] and [[Julian the Apostate]], Attack of [[Colonia Copia Claudia Augusta Lugdunum|Lugdunum]] (Lyon) by [[Laeti]], End of coordinated operation against the [[Alemanni]], [[Battle of Strasbourg|Battle of Argentoratum]], Capture of Alemannic King [[Chnodomarius]]. *358, Raid in the province of [[Raetia]] by [[Alemanni]]c [[Juthungi]], Destruction of [[Regensburg|Castra Regina]] (Regensburg) by Alemanni. *359, Execution of Roman General [[Barbatio]], Recapture of [[Moguntiacum#History|Moguntiacum]] by [[Julian the Apostate]]. *365–366, Invasion of [[Roman Gaul]] by [[Alemanni]], Alemanni pushed out of Roman Gaul. *367, Sack of [[Moguntiacum#History|Moguntiacum]] by Alemanni, [[Battle of Solicinium]]. *367–368, [[Great Conspiracy|Great Barbarian Conspiracy]] against [[Roman Britain]] and [[Roman Gaul]] by [[Saxons]] and [[Franks]], Death of [[Nectaridus]]. *367–369, Attack on [[Goths|Gothic]] [[Thervingi]] under Eastern Emperor [[Valens]].<ref name="Ammianus MarcellinusB27C5">[[Ammianus Marcellinus]], ''[[wikisource:Roman History|Historiae]]'', [[wikisource:Roman History/Book XXVII#V|book 27, chapter 5]].</ref><ref>Kulikowski, Michael, 2007, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=QXM9SH4EALgC&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s Rome's Gothic Wars]'', pp. 115-116.</ref> *368, Invasion of Alemannic territory under Emperor [[Valentinian I|Valentinian the Great]], Crossing of the [[Rhine]] by the [[Roman Empire]]. *369, Destruction of a [[Castra|fortress]] near [[Heidelberg]] by Alemanni. *370, Invasion of [[Roman Gaul]] by [[Saxons]], Death of all invading Saxons, Invasion of [[Alemanni]]c territory by [[Valentinian I|Valentinian the Great]], Rome captures thousands of [[Alemannia|Alemannic]] [[Bucinobantes]], Deposition of Alemannic King [[Macrian]], [[Huns|Hunnic]] raids on [[Goths|Gothic]] [[Greuthungi]].<ref name="Zosimus, Historia Nova, book 4">[[Zosimus]], ''[http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/zosimus01_book1.htm Historia Nova]'', [http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/zosimus04_book4.htm book 4].</ref><ref name="Ammianus MarcellinusB31C3" /><ref name="PhilostorgiusBook9Chap7">[[Philostorgius]], ''[[wikisource:Ecclesiastical history (Philostorgius)|Ecclesiastical history]]'', [[wikisource:Ecclesiastical history (Philostorgius)/Epitome of book IX|book 9]], chapter 17.</ref><ref name="Sozomen, Ecclesiastical_history, book 6, chapter 37">Sozomen, ''[[wikisource:Ecclesiastical history (Sozomen)|Ecclesiastical History]]'', book 6, chapter 37.</ref><ref name="Heather, Peter 1998, pp. 98-104">Heather, Peter, 1998, ''The Goths'', pp. 98-104.</ref><ref name="Kulikowski, Michael 2007, pp. 124-128">Kulikowski, Michael, 2007, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=QXM9SH4EALgC&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s Rome's Gothic Wars]'', pp. 124-128.</ref> *374, Assassination of Quadic King [[Quadi|Gabinius]], Invasion of former Illyricum by [[Quadi]] and Sarmatians. *375, Pillaging of Quadi lands by the Roman Empire, Western Emperor [[Valentinian I|Valentinian the Great]] dies during peace negotiations. [[File:Huns empire.png|300px|thumb|[[Huns#Unified Empire under Attila|Empire of the Huns]], pushing the Germanic tribes over the Limes into the Roman Empire.]] *376, [[Ostrogoths#Hunnic invasions|Invasion of the Huns]], Hunnic war against [[Visigoths]] and [[Ostrogoths]], Suicide of [[Goths|Gothic]] King [[Ermanaric]], [[Goths|Gothic]] King [[Vithimiris|Vithimer]] dies in battle.<ref>Heather, Peter, 2010, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=gbUlnaHlHS0C&source=gbs_navlinks_s Empires and barbarians]'', p. 215.</ref><ref>Heather, Peter, 1995, ''The English Historical Review'', ''[http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-16733921/huns-and-end-roman.html The Huns and the end of the Roman Empire in Western Europe]''</ref> *376–382, Hunnic raids on Gothic [[Thervingi]] ([[Visigoths]]),<ref name="Zosimus, Historia Nova, book 4"/><ref name="Ammianus MarcellinusB31C3">Ammianus Marcellinus, ''[[wikisource:Roman History|Historiae]]'', [[wikisource:Roman History/Book XXXI#III|book 31, chapter 3]].</ref><ref name="PhilostorgiusBook9Chap7"/><ref name="Sozomen, Ecclesiastical_history, book 6, chapter 37"/><ref name="Heather, Peter 1998, pp. 98-104"/><ref name="Kulikowski, Michael 2007, pp. 124-128"/> [[Gothic War (376–382)|Gothic War]],<ref name="Zosimus, Historia Nova, book 4"/><ref name="PhilostorgiusBook9Chap7"/><ref name="Sozomen, Ecclesiastical_history, book 6, chapter 37"/><ref>Ammianus Marcellinus, ''[[wikisource:Roman History|Historiae]]'', [[wikisource:Roman History/Book XXXI#V|book 31, chapters 5-16]].</ref><ref>[[Socrates Scholasticus]], ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=0hDLtLLNoqAC&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s The Ecclesiastical History]'', book 4, chapters 34-38 & book 5, chapter 1.</ref><ref>[[Peter Heather|Heather, Peter]], 1998, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Szd_GnZNTXcC&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s The Goths]'', pp. 130-138.</ref><ref>Kulikowski, Michael, 2007, ''Rome's Gothic Wars'', pp. 130-153.</ref> Plundering and destruction throughout the Balkans by Goths. **377, [[Battle of the Willows]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://romanhistorybooksandmore.freeservers.com/r_day-of-barbarians.htm|title=The Day of the Barbarians: The Battle That Led to the Fall of the Roman Empire|last=Hahn|first=Irene|work=Book review|publisher=http://romanhistorybooksandmore.freeservers.com|year=2007|accessdate=2008-04-19}}</ref> Gothic chieftain [[Farnobius]] dies in battle. **378, [[Battle of Adrianople]],<ref>Ammianus Marcellinus, ''Historiae'', book 31, chapters 12–14.</ref><ref name="Historia Nova book 4">Zosimus, ''Historia Nova'', book 4.</ref> Eastern Emperor [[Valens]] dies in battle, Begin of the Fall of the [[Western Roman Empire]].<ref name="Roman Empire">[http://www.roman-empire.net/army/adrianople.html Roman Empire – Adrianople] roman-empire.net. Illustrated History of the Roman Empire. Retrieved April 2, 2007.</ref> *377–378, Invasion of [[Thrace]] and [[Moesia]] by Gothic [[Greuthungi]] led by chieftain [[Alatheus]]. *378, Invasion of [[Alsace]] by [[Alemanni]], [[Battle of Argentovaria]], Extermination of [[Alemannia|Alemannic]] [[Lentienses]], Alemannic King [[Priarius]] dies in battle. *380, [[Battle of Thessalonica (380)|Battle of Thessalonica]], Death of Gothic chieftain [[Fritigern]], Begin of naval raids by [[Saxons]], Begin of the [[Anglo-Saxon settlement of Britain|Migration of the Saxons]]. *382, Peace between Rome and the Goths, Large Gothic contingents of [[Thervingi]], [[Taifali]] and [[Victohali]] settle along the southern Danube frontier in the province of [[Thrace]]. *383, Failed raid in the province of [[Raetia]] by Alemannic [[Juthungi]]. *387, Failed Invasion of [[Thrace]] and [[Moesia]] by Gothic [[Greuthungi]] led by chieftain [[Alatheus]], Greuthungi chieftain Alatheus dies in battle. *390, [[Massacre of Thessalonica]]. *392, Emperor [[Valentinian II]] is hanged, Frankish General [[Arbogast (general)|Arbogast]] names [[Eugenius]] to be Western Emperor. *394, 20,000 Gothic mercenaries support Eastern Emperor [[Theodosius I|Theodosius the Great]] in the [[Battle of the Frigidus]], Suicide of Frankish General [[Arbogast (general)|Arbogast]], Execution of puppet Western Emperor [[Eugenius]]. *395, Assassination of Consul [[Rufinus (consul)|Rufinus]] by [[Goths|Gothic]] [[mercenary|mercenaries]].
===5th century===
''For the timeline of events in Britannia after its abandonment by Emperor Valentinian III, see [[Timeline of conflict in Anglo-Saxon Britain]].''
{{Campaignbox Fall of Western Roman Empire}} {{Campaignbox Rome against the Visigoths}} {{Campaignbox Rome against the Anglo-Saxons}}
*401–402, Raid in [[Raetia]] by [[Vandals]]. *401–403, Invasion of Italy by [[Visigoths]] under [[Alaric I]], [[Gothic War (402-403)|Gothic War]]. **402, [[Battle of Pollentia]]. **403, [[Battle of Verona (402)|Battle of Verona]], Visigoths pushed into former [[Illyricum (Roman province)|Illyricum]] by [[Stilicho]]. *405–406, Siege of [[Florence|Florentina]],<ref name="Heather 205">Heather, Peter, ''The Goths'', p. 205</ref> [[Battle of Faesulae (406)|Battle of Faesulae]],<ref>Jaques, Tony. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Dh6jydKXikoC&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s Dictionary of Battles and Sieges: F-O.]'' Greenwood Publishing Group, 2007, ISBN 978-0-313-33538-9, p. 345.</ref> Execution of Gothic King [[Radagaisus]],<ref name="Heather 194">Heather, Peter, ''The Goths'', p. 194</ref> 12,000 Gothic higher-status fighters are drafted into the Roman army.<ref name="Heather 205" /><ref name="Heather 194" /> *406, War between [[Franks]] and [[Vandals]], [[Battle of Mainz (406)|Battle of Moguntiacum]], Vandal King [[Godigisel]] dies in battle, [[Alans]] under King [[Respendial]] rescue the [[Vandals]], [[Crossing of the Rhine|Invasion of Gaul]] by Vandals, [[Suebi]], [[Burgundians]] and Alans, Fall of [[Roman Gaul]]. *408, Failed invasion of [[Moesia]] by Huns and Germanic mercenaries led by [[Uldin|Uldin the Hun]], Capture of thousands of [[Germanic peoples|Germanic]] mercenaries, Execution of Roman General [[Stilicho]], Slaughter of wives and children of barbarian ''[[foederati]]'', [[Siege of Rome (408)|Siege of Rome]] by Visigoths, Attacks on [[Roman Britain]] by [[Saxons]]. [[Image:Hispania 418 AD.PNG|300px|thumb|[[Vandals#The Vandal Kingdom in North Africa|Kingdom of the Vandals]] (yellow) and their allies the [[Sarmatians|Sarmatian]] [[Alans]] before the Invasion of [[Africa (Roman province)|Roman Africa]], c. 418]] *409, 2nd [[Siege of Rome (409)|Siege of Rome]] by Visigoths, Invasion of [[Hispania|Roman Spain]] by Vandals, [[Suebi]] ([[Marcomanni]], [[Quadi]], [[Buri (Germanic tribe)|Buri]]) and Alans. *410, [[Sack of Rome (410)|Sack of Rome]] by [[Visigoths]], Begin of attacks on Vandals by Visigoths, Begin of Barbarian raids by [[Picts]], [[Scoti]] and Irish [[Celts]], [[End of Roman rule in Britain]], '''[[Suebi|Suevi]] establish a [[Suebic Kingdom of Galicia|Kingdom in Galicia]]'''. *411, [[Jovinus]] declares himself Western Roman Emperor with aid of the [[Burgundians]], [[Franks]] and Alans, [[Burgundian Kingdom#Burgundian kingdoms|Burgundians establish a Kingdom]] left of the Rhine under King [[Gundahar]]. *413, Capture of [[Narbonne]] and [[Toulouse]] by Visigoths led by King [[Ataulf]], Usurper Jovinus is executed, Sack of [[Trier]] by [[Franks]]. *421, Sack of [[Trier]] by [[Franks]]. *422, Capture and Execution of Frankish King [[Theudemeres]] by Romans, Attack on Vandals by Romans. *426–436, Campaigns against the [[Visigoths]] in southern Gaul under Western Emperor [[Valentinian III]], [[Battle of Narbonne (436)|Battle of Narbonne]], Capture of Visigothic chieftain [[Anaolsus]]. *428, Invasion of Northern Gaul by [[Salian Franks]] led by King [[Chlodio]]. *428–431, Failed Roman campaigns against [[Salian Franks]], [[Alemannia|Alemannic]] [[Juthungi]] on the [[Rhine]] and [[Danube]]. [[File:Vandalesmaximum.png|300px|thumb|[[Vandals#The Vandal Kingdom in North Africa|Kingdom of the Vandals]] in North Africa, c. 429.]] *429–439, Invasion of [[Africa (Roman province)|Africa]] by [[Vandals]] led by Vandal King [[Genseric]], [[Siege of Hippo Regius]], Capture of [[Carthage]] by Vandals, Capture of Roman navy by Vandals, Pillaging of [[Sicily]], Begin of pirate raids by Vandals. *431, Invasion to the [[Somme River]] by [[Salian Franks]]. *436–437, Invasion of [[Burgundians|Burgundian]] [[Rhineland]] by [[Hun]] mercenaries controlled by Rome, Burgundian King [[Gundahar]] dies in battle. *c. 443, Britain plunges into civil war, [[Groans of the Britons]], Britain is abandoned by Western Emperor [[Valentinian III]]. *448, Defeat of the [[Salian Franks]] in the [[Battle of Vicus Helena]] by Roman General [[Flavius Aetius|Aëtius]], Frankish King [[Chlodio]] dies in battle. *451, Invasion of [[Gaul]] by the [[Huns]] with [[Franks|Frankish]], [[Goths|Gothic]] and [[Burgundians|Burgundian]] mercenaries led by [[Attila|Attila the Hun]], Sack of [[Trier]], Attack on [[Metz]], Siege of [[Orléans]], Coalition of Romans, Franks and [[Visigoths]] led by General [[Flavius Aetius|Aëtius]] stop the Huns in the [[Battle of Châlons]], Visigothic King [[Theodoric I]] dies in battle. *452, Invasion of northern Italy under [[Attila|Attila the Hun]]: [[Sack of Aquileia]], [[Vicetia]], [[Verona]], [[Brescia|Brixia]], [[Bergamum]] and [[Milan]]. *453, Hunnic and Germanic attacks on [[Constantinople]], [[Attila|Attila the Hun]] dies during heavy drinking. *454, Assassination of Roman General [[Flavius Aetius|Aëtius]], [[Gepids]] establish [[Kingdom of the Gepids|a kingdom]] in [[Pannonia]]. *455, [[Sack of Rome (455)|Sack of Rome]] by [[Vandals]], Capture of Empress [[Licinia Eudoxia]] by Vandals. *456, [[Visigoths]] defeat the [[Suebic Kingdom of Galicia]] in the [[Battle of Órbigo (456)|Battle of Órbigo]]. *458, Defeat of the [[Visigoths]] in southern [[Gaul]] in the [[Battle of Arelate]]. [[File:Europe and the Near East at 476 AD.png|thumbnail|300px|Europe in the late 5th century (476-486).]] *459, Seizure of [[Trier]] by [[Franks]]. *461, Seventeen Vandal ships destroy forty Roman ships in [[Battle of Cartagena (461)|a surprise attack]]. *463, [[Battle of Orleans (463)|Battle of Orleans]]. *465, [[Ostrogoths|Ostrogothic]] King [[Valamir]] dies in battle. *468, Invasion of the [[Vandals|Vandal Kingdom]] by the [[Byzantine Empire]], Defeat of the Byzantine Empire by the [[Vandals]] in the [[Battle of Cape Bon (468)|Battle of Cape Bon]]. *469, [[Ostrogoths]] decisively defeat an alliance of Germanic and Roman forces in the [[Battle of Bolia]],<ref name="google1990">{{cite book|author= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xsQxcJvaLjAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=History+of+the+Goths&hl=no&sa=X&ei=AAh-T_P3LsSp0QXB2-GVDg&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Bassianae%20Dengizich&f=false |title=History of the Goths |publisher=University of California Press |date=13 February 1990 |accessdate=5 April 2012}}</ref> Fall of the [[Huns#Unified Empire under Attila|Hunnic Empire]], [[Visigoths]] thwarted an attack by an alliance of [[Breton people|Bretons]] and Romans in the [[Battle of Déols]]. *472, Revolt in [[Thrace]] by [[Ostrogoths]] led by chieftain [[Theodoric Strabo]]. *476, Revolt of [[Heruli]], [[Scirii]] and [[Turcilingi]] mercenaries, [[Battle of Ravenna (476)|Battle of Ravenna]], Germanic [[Heruli]] chieftain [[Odoacer]] becomes [[King of Italy]], [[Fall of the Western Roman Empire]]. *486, [[Franks]] under [[Merovingian dynasty|Merovingian]] King [[Clovis I]] defeat the [[Kingdom of Soissons]] in the [[Battle of Soissons (486)|Battle of Soissons]], Fall of the [[Kingdom of Soissons]]. *489, [[Theodoric the Great]] defeats [[Odoacer]] in the [[Battle of Isonzo (489)|Battle of Isonzo]], [[Battle of Verona (489)|Battle of Verona]].
===6th century=== {{Campaignbox Rome against the Vandals}} {{Campaignbox Rome against the Ostrogoths}}
[[File:Visigothic Kingdom.png|300px|thumb|[[Visigothic Kingdom|Kingdom of the Visigoths]] (orange), [[Suebic Kingdom of Galicia|Kingdom of the Suebi]] (green), [[Kingdom of Burgundy|Kingdom of the Burgundians]], [[Francia|Kingdom of the Franks]] (purple), Kingdom of the Vandals (yellow), c. 490.]] *526, Raid against Gothic [[Gepids|Gepidae]] by Byzantine General [[Belisarius]]. *533–534, Invasion of [[North Africa]] by the Byzantine Empire, [[Vandalic War]]. **533, [[Battle of Ad Decimum]], Capture of [[Carthage]] by the [[Byzantine Empire]]. **533, [[Battle of Tricamarum]], Destruction of the [[Vandals|Vandal Kingdom]] by the [[Byzantine Empire]], Fall of the [[Vandals#The Vandal Kingdom in North Africa|Kingdom of the Vandals]]. *535–554, Invasion of [[Italy]] by the [[Byzantine Empire]],<ref name=europe400>{{cite web | title = World Timeline of Europe AD 400-800 Early medieval | publisher = The British Museum | year = 2005 | url = http://www.worldtimelines.org.uk/world/europe/AD400-800 | accessdate = 2009-04-06}}</ref> [[Gothic War (535–554)|Ostrogothic War]]. **535, Capture of Sicily by Byzantine General [[Belisarius]]. **536, Capture of [[Naples]] and [[Rome]] by Byzantine General [[Belisarius]]. **537–538, [[Siege of Rome (537–538)|Siege of Rome]] by [[Ostrogoths]]. **540, Capture of [[Milan|Mediolanum]] and the Ostrogothic capital [[Ravenna]] by Byzantine General [[Belisarius]], Capture of [[Ostrogoths|Ostrogothic]] King [[Witiges]]. **541–542, [[Plague of Justinian|Bubonic plague]] wipes out most of the farming community of the [[Decline of the Roman Empire|former Roman Empire]] and leaving dead an estimated 25 million people across the world, Begin of territorial decline until the 9th century. **541–544, Recapture of Northern Italy by [[Ostrogoths]]. ***542, [[Battle of Faventia]], [[Battle of Mucellium]]. ***543, [[Siege of Naples (543)|Siege of Naples]]. **546, [[Sack of Rome (546)|Sack of Rome]] by [[Ostrogoths]]. **c. 548, Recapture of Rome by the [[Byzantine Empire]]. **549–550, [[Siege of Rome (549–550)|Siege and Capture of Rome]] by [[Ostrogoths]]. **551, [[Battle of Sena Gallica (551)|Battle of Sena Gallica]], Capture of Ostrogothic chieftain [[Gibal]], Demoralization of Gothic army. **552, Byzantine Empire with aid of the [[Heruli]] and [[Lombards]] defeat the [[Ostrogoths]] in the [[Battle of Taginae]], Ostrogothic King [[Totila]] dies on the run, Defeat of Gothic [[Gepids]] in the [[Battle of Asfeld]] against [[Lombards]] (Longbeards), [[Gepids|Gepid]] King [[Thurisind]] dies in battle. **552–553, Capture of Rome and Siege of [[Cumae]] by Byzantine General [[Narses]], [[Battle of Mons Lactarius]], Ostrogothic king [[Teia]] dies in battle, Fall of the [[Ostrogothic Kingdom]]. [[File:Justinian Byzanz.png|300px|thumb|The [[Byzantine Empire]] at the End of the Antiquity in 565.]] *554, Byzantine General [[Narses]] defeats the [[Franks]] and [[Alemanni]] in the [[Battle of the Volturnus (554)|Battle of the Volturnus]].<ref name="Haldon39">Haldon, John, 2008, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=YRfjHwAACAAJ&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s The Byzantine Wars]'', p. 39.</ref> *c. 558–561, Failed Uprising of the Ostrogoth [[Widin]].<ref>Amory, Patrick, 2003, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=7ndeDi_fwq0C&hl=en&source=gbs_navlinks_s People and Identity in Ostrogothic Italy, 489-554].''</ref> *567, [[Lombards]] decisively defeat the Gepids, [[Gepids|Gepid]] King [[Cunimund]] dies in battle, Fall of the [[Kingdom of the Gepids|Kingdom of the Gepidae]]. *568–c. 572, Invasion of Northern Italy by [[Lombards]], [[Bavarians]], [[Gepids]] and [[Saxons]], Longbeards (Lombards) establish a Kingdom in Northern Italy (capital [[Pavia]]), Begin of End of Byzantine rule. **569, Seizure of [[Cividale del Friuli]], [[Vicenza]], [[Verona]], [[Brescia]] and [[Milan|Mediolanum]] by [[Lombards]]. **570–572, [[Siege of Pavia (569–572)|Siege of Ticinum]], Seizure of [[Tuscany]] by [[Lombards]].
